<span style="font-size:.9em;line-height:134%;display:block;"><strong>Abstract</strong>: DNA assembly is low throughput and unreliable. Implementation of DNA design software is usually done by hand which is low-throughput and error-prone. Here, we present an open-source python package to integrate DNA assembly software with the OT-2 liquid handling robot. Our package reduces the time, training, costs, and wastes associated with molecular biology. We demonstrate the flexibility  and versatility of DNtegrAte by demonstrating PCRs and multipart assemblies.</span>

## Body row {data-height=72.5}

### **Introduction** {data-width=500}

#### <span style="font-size:.8em;">The Troublesome Cloning Workflow</span>
<span style="font-size:.7em;margin: 0 0 0 -15px;display:block;">
<ul>
  <li>Extensive training and high error-rates are typical in synbio labs due to the complexity of the cloning workflow in practice.</li>
  <li>Researchers spend more time and resources on executing the workflow rather than actually engineering biology.</li>
</ul>
</span>

<figure>

<center><img src="resources/fig1wman.png" style="width:90%;margin: 20px 0px 20px 0px;"></center>

<figcaption align = "center"><b><span style="font-size:.9em;line-height:134%;display:block;">Fig. 1: **The Cloning Workflow** - (A) Design constructs with existing design software platforms. (B) Order primers and amplify parts (C) Assemble new constructs via *in vivo* assembly (IVA), goldengate, etc. (D) Maintain constructs in *E. coli* (E) Use for downstream applications.</span></b></figcaption>

</figure>

### **Validating DNtegrAte with PCR and Multi-part *in vivo* Assembly** {data-width=800}


<figure>

<center><img src="resources/posterfig416.png" style="width:100%;"></center>

<figcaption align = "center"><b><span style="font-size:.6em;line-height:134%;display:block;">Fig. 2: Cloning with DNtegrAte - (A) DNtegrAte PCR protocol was verified by successful amplification of DNA fragments varying in length and annealing temperature. (B) A graphical depiction of the optimal annealing temperature gradient calculated for the PCR. (C) DNtegrAte IVA protocol was verified by successful amplification of each assembly fragment. (D) Consistent transformation efficiency, correct antibiotic resistance, and correct chromoprotein expression further validate the IVA protocol.</span></b></figcaption>

</figure>


 
### **Data and Methods** {data-width=300}

#### <span style="font-size:.8em;">Software Design:</span>

<span style="font-size:.7em;margin: 0 0 0 -15px;display:block;">
<ul>
  <li>Protocol scripts are flexible and fully automated.</li>
  <li>GUI for specifying parameters like template concentration, PCR volume, etc. is included.</li>
  <li>Input and output files are automatically generated and archived in dated directories available at github.com/plantsynbio/opentrons.</li>
</ul>
</span>

#### <span style="font-size:.8em;">Data Collection:</span>

<span style="font-size:.7em;margin: 0 0 0 -15px;display:block;">
<ul>
  
  <li>The multi-fragment PCR for gradient algorithm validation (fig 2A, 2B) was based on a design for an auxin signaling protein motif deletion.</li>
  <li>The IVA for assembly protocol validation (fig 2C, 2D) was based on a chromoprotein swap design which assembles two backbone fragments from a blue plasmid with an Amp resistance fragment, and each color to produce products in fig 2D.</li>
</ul>
</span>
